system.biography:
Archons are incredibly powerful beings of law and good, existing to oppose chaos and evil. They work both directly and indirectly, assisting adventurers in their quests against evil forces. Archons have the bodies of giant eagles with golden-feathered wings. Male archons possess the head, arms, and torso of a giant, muscular man, while females have a dragonlike neck and three heads: two bull's heads and a central human-like head.

In combat, the male archon can wield any human weapon, often using enchanted ones, while the female can either gore with her bull heads for 3d10 damage or breathe a 10' cone of fire for 4d6 damage. They are immune to fire, poison, and 1st-4th level spells of all types.

Archons can cast spells as 12th level clerics and teleport at will. Once per day, they may use a "bolt of purity" to make victims become Lawful and peaceful for 2d6 turns, or create a "sword of flame" that inflicts 4d8 damage. They live in small family units of one mated pair and 1d3 young, and are rarely encountered with their offspring.

Terrain: Any, any Planar.

Load Capacity: 5,000 cn at full speed; 10,000 cn at half speed.

encumbrance.label: Unencumbered
encumbrance.desc: Free to move without any hindrance.

system.description: Once per day, the Archon can use a bolt of purity, which causes all victims to become Lawful and peaceful for [[/r 2d6 #lawful and peaceful for this many turns]] turns. It does not cause damage and removes all evil thoughts (no saving throw).

gm.notes: Bolt of Purity causing Lawful and peaceful behavior.

system.description: The Teleport ability allows a character or creature to instantly move from one location to another without traversing the space in between, as long as the new location is within their sight or a known place.

The saving throw against "Stone or Paralysis" protects a character from attacks or effects that could freeze them in place (paralysis) or turn them into stone. If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. The duration or permanence of these effects is specified by the source, and successful saving throws avoid them entirely​​​.
Archons can cast spells as 12th level clerics. They are immune to fire, poison, and 1st through 4th level spells of all types.

The Magic Wand saving throw is used to avoid the effects of attacks or abilities activated through magical wands, such as paralysis rays or damage-dealing beams. A successful save, rolled on a d20, indicates that the character avoids or mitigates the harmful effects. The target number to save is determined by the character's class and level, as found on the saving throw table​​.

The Death Ray or Poison saving throw is a roll made by a character to resist deadly effects like instant death or paralysis from poisons, spells, or traps. The player rolls a d20 and compares it to their class- and level-specific target number on the saving throw table; success means avoiding or mitigating the harm. A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.
A female Archon can breathe a 10' cone of fire, causing 4d6 points of damage.

A cleric who chooses to establish a stronghold with the approval of his clerical order is known as a "land-owning cleric." This term is convenient, as a land-owning cleric can still adventure with friends and is not bound to his land.

Advantages: The cleric can advance within his order, receive financial support for building the stronghold, and potentially expand his lands, leading to significant wealth.

Disadvantages: The cleric becomes the primary authority for his order in the area, bearing responsibilities to the local populace that may hinder his ability to travel with old adventuring companions or present him with challenging issues.

When a 9th-level cleric decides to build a stronghold, he must seek permission from a superior, either an official of his order or a local ruler. The ruler should grant the land unless there are past issues; in such cases, the ruler may require a service, like a quest, before approval. The DM will determine if the cleric's order has the authority to grant land based on the campaign's setting.

If the cleric has a clean record, his order may assist with construction costs, typically covering up to 50% of the expenses. The player can design the stronghold, and the DM will assess the costs, deciding what portion the order will fund. Regardless of the financial support, the stronghold remains the cleric's property, and he cannot deny access to order members, nor can he be reassigned against his will.

Once the stronghold is built, a number of lower-level clerics (typically 1d6) will arrive to assist with its clerical functions. These clerics are there to help operate the stronghold, not to join the cleric on adventures. The DM should create each assistant cleric with their own name, personality, background, goals, and abilities.

If the cleric manages his land and serves his order well, he is likely to gain power within the clerical hierarchy, receive additional land, and see an increase in tax income from the growing settlements around his stronghold.

The saving throw for Spells or Magic Staff includes resistance against magical effects cast by rods, staves, wands, or through spells. A successful save, rolled on a d20, often reduces or negates the spell's effects entirely. This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.

The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.

A normal sword is a one-handed sword with a straight or curved blade 2’ to 3’ long. This category of sword encompasses a variety of different styles of sword, ranging from scimitars to broadswords and even rapiers.
system.unidentifiedDesc: A normal sword is a one-handed sword with a straight or curved blade 2’ to 3’ long. This category of sword encompasses a variety of different styles of sword, ranging from scimitars to broadswords and even rapiers.

system.description: The Archon's feathers provide extreme protection, representing an Armor Class of -6.
system.unidentifiedDesc: The Archon's feathers provide extreme protection, representing an Armor Class of -6.

system.description: Clerics do not cast spells at 1st level but gain access to divine spells at 2nd level, progressing in power as they level up. Clerics do not need spellbooks but must pray for spells each day.

The Flight ability allows a character or creature to move through the air, either through magical means or natural capabilities, such as having wings. This ability enables the user to ascend, descend, and navigate in three-dimensional space, often at a specified speed. Flight may come with limitations, such as a maximum altitude, duration, or specific conditions for its use.
Once per day, the Archon may create a sword of flame, which lasts for three turns. It deals 4d8 damage on a successful hit.
system.unidentifiedDesc: Once per day, the Archon may create a sword of flame, which lasts for three turns. It deals 4d8 damage on a successful hit.

system.description: A female Archon's bull head gore attack, dealing 3d10 damage.

Lich--------------------1197TTTT

Notes:

  • 7, 9, or 11: Number needed to turn successfully.
  • T: Automatic turn; turns 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D: Automatic destroy; destroys 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D+: Automatic destroy; destroys 3d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D#: Automatic destroy; destroys 4d6 Hit Dice of undead.

Clerics have the divine power to repel or even destroy certain undead creatures, such as skeletons, zombies, and more powerful types. This ability is known as Turn Undead. When encountering these undead beings, the cleric can choose to either engage them in combat with weapons or spells, or attempt to turn them.

To turn undead, the cleric simply announces the intention to do so to the Dungeon Master. No holy symbol or other item is needed unless the DM specifies otherwise. The success of this attempt depends on the cleric’s level and the type of undead faced, as indicated on the Turning Undead table.

If the cleric succeeds, one or more undead creatures will flee or be destroyed immediately, depending on the result. However, a failed attempt means that particular undead creature cannot be turned by the cleric again during the same encounter. Multiple attempts are allowed in future encounters.

Should the attempt succeed, the Dungeon Master rolls to determine how many Hit Dice worth of undead are turned. At least one undead creature will always be affected. A turned undead creature will retreat as far as possible, but it has not been destroyed and may return after some time.
A female Archon can breathe a 10' cone of fire, causing 4d6 points of damage.
